article:
2023 Asia Cup

The 2023 Asia Cup was the 16th edition of the Asia Cup, a biennial international cricket tournament organized by the Asian Cricket Council (ACC). The tournament was held in Sri Lanka from August 30 to September 17, 2023. Six teams participated in the tournament, including India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Afghanistan, and Nepal.

#Background

The 2023 Asia Cup was originally scheduled to be held in Pakistan, but due to security concerns, the tournament was shifted to Sri Lanka. The Sri Lankan cricket board agreed to host the tournament, and the ACC announced the revised schedule and venues. The tournament was played in the ODI format, with a total of 13 matches played over 19 days.

#Format

The 2023 Asia Cup followed a round-robin format, with the six participating teams divided into two groups of three teams each. The top two teams from each group qualified for the Super Four stage, where they played each other in a round-robin format. The top two teams from the Super Four stage qualified for the final.

#Teams and qualification

Six teams participated in the 2023 Asia Cup, including:

* India (full member)
* Pakistan (full member)
* Sri Lanka (full member)
* Bangladesh (full member)
* Afghanistan (full member)
* Nepal (associate member)

All six teams qualified for the tournament by virtue of their ACC membership.

#Squads

Each team was required to submit a squad of 15 players for the tournament. The squads were announced by the respective cricket boards in August 2023.

#Venues

The 2023 Asia Cup was held at three venues in Sri Lanka:

* R. Premadasa Stadium, Colombo
* Galle International Stadium, Galle
* Pallekele International Cricket Stadium, Kandy

#Match officials

##Match referees

The ACC appointed the following match referees for the tournament:

* Steve Davis (Australia)
* David Boon (Australia)
* Jeff Crowe (New Zealand)

##Umpires

The following umpires were appointed for the tournament:

* Marais Erasmus (South Africa)
* Kumar Dharmasena (Sri Lanka)
* Michael Gough (England)
* Sundaram Ravi (India)
* Ahsan Raza (Pakistan)
* Richard Kettleborough (England)

article:
Sinking of the Moskva

The sinking of the Moskva was a major naval incident that occurred on April 14, 2022, during the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The Moskva, a Slava-class cruiser, was the flagship of the Russian Black Sea Fleet and one of the most powerful warships in the Russian Navy. The incident was widely reported and had significant implications for the ongoing conflict.

#Background

The Moskva was commissioned in 1983 and was designed to provide air defense and anti-submarine capabilities to the Soviet Navy. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the ship was inherited by the Russian Navy and underwent several modernization programs. At the time of the incident, the Moskva was the flagship of the Russian Black Sea Fleet and was participating in the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

In the days leading up to the incident, the Moskva had been involved in several operations, including the blockade of Ukrainian ports and the provision of gunfire support to Russian ground troops. The ship was also equipped with a range of advanced sensors and communication systems, making it a key asset for the Russian military.

#Sinking

##Ukrainian account

According to the Ukrainian military, the Moskva was struck by two Neptune anti-ship missiles fired by Ukrainian forces on the evening of April 13, 2022. The missiles were reportedly launched from a location near the port city of Odesa, and the Ukrainian military claimed that the ship was hit in the port side of the hull.

The Ukrainian account of the incident was supported by several eyewitnesses, who reported seeing the ship on fire and listing to one side. The Ukrainian military also released a statement claiming that the Moskva had sunk, although this was not immediately confirmed by Russian officials.

##Russian account

The Russian account of the incident differed significantly from the Ukrainian version. According to the Russian Defense Ministry, the Moskva sank on April 14, 2022, after a fire broke out on board. The ministry claimed that the fire was caused by an explosion of ammunition on the ship, and that the crew had attempted to put out the blaze but were unable to do so.

The Russian account did not mention any involvement by Ukrainian forces, and instead attributed the incident to an accident. However, this explanation was met with skepticism by many observers, who pointed out that the ship had been involved in combat operations in the days leading up to the incident.

##Other early observations

In the hours following the incident, several other observers reported seeing the Moskva on fire and listing to one side. These reports came from a range of sources, including satellite imagery and eyewitness accounts from ships in the area.

One of the most significant early observations came from a US defense official, who reported that the Moskva had been hit by a missile. This report was later confirmed by other sources, including the Ukrainian military.

##Missile strike

The evidence suggests that the Moskva was indeed hit by a missile, likely a Neptune anti-ship missile fired by Ukrainian forces. The missile strike would have caused significant damage to the ship, including a breach of the hull and a fire that spread rapidly throughout the vessel.

The use of a Neptune missile would have been a significant escalation of the conflict, as it would have required the Ukrainian military to have acquired and deployed a sophisticated anti-ship capability. However, the Ukrainian military had been working to develop this capability in the months leading up to the incident, and it is likely that they had acquired the necessary technology and training to carry out the attack.

##Images and video of the sinking ship

In the days following the incident, several images and videos of the sinking Moskva were released. These images showed the ship on fire and listing to one side, with smoke billowing from the hull.

The images and video were widely shared on social media, and provided a graphic illustration of the severity of the incident. They also helped to confirm the Ukrainian account of the incident, which had been met with skepticism by some observers.

#Casualties

The exact number of casualties from the sinking of the Moskva is not known, although it is believed to be significant. The Russian military reported that one sailor had died in the incident, although this number is likely to be an underestimate.

The Ukrainian military claimed that the ship had a crew of over 500 sailors, and that many of these had been killed or injured in the incident. However, this number has not been confirmed, and it is likely that the true number of casualties will never be known.

#Impact

The sinking of the Moskva had a significant impact on the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. The incident marked a major escalation of the conflict, and highlighted the growing capabilities of the Ukrainian military.

The incident also had significant implications for the Russian military, which had been relying on the Moskva as a key asset in the conflict. The loss of the ship would have reduced the Russian military's ability to project power in the region, and would have required them to reassess their strategy.

#Aftermath

In the days following the incident, the Russian military launched a series of airstrikes against Ukrainian targets. These airstrikes were seen as a response to the sinking of the Moskva, and marked a further escalation of the conflict.

The incident also led to a significant increase in tensions between Russia and the West, with several countries condemning the Russian military's actions. The incident highlighted the growing risks of the conflict, and the need for a diplomatic solution to the crisis.

The qualification for the 2023 WTA Finals was based on the WTA rankings as of October 22, 2023. The top eight singles players and the top eight doubles teams in the WTA rankings qualified for the tournament.

The 2023 WTA Finals followed a round-robin format in the group stage, with the top two players from each group advancing to the semifinals. The semifinals and final were played in a knockout format.

* The winner of the head-to-head match between the tied players was ranked higher.

article:
Liga 1 (Indonesia)

Liga 1 is the top professional football league in Indonesia. It was founded in 1994 and is contested by 18 clubs. The league is operated by the Football Association of Indonesia (PSSI) and is considered one of the most popular sports leagues in the country.

# History

## Origins

The concept of a national football league in Indonesia dates back to the 1930s, when the country was still a Dutch colony. The first national championship was held in 1931, with teams from various regions competing in a knockout format. However, the league was not formalized until after Indonesia gained independence in 1945.

## Foundation

The modern Indonesian football league was established in 1979, with the creation of the Galatama league. The Galatama was a semi-professional league that featured teams from various regions, but it was not a national league in the classical sense. In 1990, the PSSI introduced the Perserikatan league, which was a national championship featuring teams from various regions.

## Dualism

In 1994, the PSSI introduced the Liga Indonesia, which was a professional league that replaced the Perserikatan. However, the Liga Indonesia was not the only top-level league in the country. The Galatama league continued to operate, and there were several other regional leagues that were not affiliated with the PSSI. This led to a period of dualism, where there were multiple top-level leagues operating in the country.

## Government intervention and FIFA suspension

In 2011, the Indonesian government intervened in the league, citing concerns over the PSSI's management and corruption. The government imposed a freeze on the league, which led to a suspension by FIFA. The suspension was lifted in 2016, after the PSSI reformed its management structure and introduced new reforms.

## Name change

In 2017, the league was rebranded as Liga 1, as part of a broader effort to rebrand Indonesian football. The name change was intended to make the league more attractive to sponsors and fans.

# Competition format

## Competition

Liga 1 is a double-round robin league, where each team plays every other team twice. The team with the most points at the end of the season is crowned the champion. In the event of a tie, the team with the better goal difference is declared the winner.

## Promotion and relegation

Liga 1 features a system of promotion and relegation with the Liga 2, which is the second tier of Indonesian football. The bottom three teams in Liga 1 are relegated to Liga 2, while the top three teams in Liga 2 are promoted to Liga 1.

## Video assistant referee

In 2019, Liga 1 introduced the video assistant referee (VAR) system, which is used to review decisions made by the referee. The VAR system is used to review goals, penalties, and direct red cards.

# Clubs

## Champions

The most successful club in Liga 1 is Persipura Jayapura, which has won four titles. Other successful clubs include Persija Jakarta, which has won three titles, and Arema FC, which has won two titles.

## Performance by clubs

The performance of clubs in Liga 1 varies widely. Some clubs, such as Persipura Jayapura and Persija Jakarta, have consistently performed well, while others have struggled.

## 2024–25 season

The 2024–25 season will feature 18 clubs, including several new teams that were promoted from Liga 2.

## Former clubs

Several clubs have competed in Liga 1 over the years, but are no longer in the league. These include Persebaya Surabaya, which was relegated to Liga 2 in 2020, and PSIS Semarang, which was relegated in 2019.

## All-time Liga 1 table

# Foreign players

Liga 1 allows each team to sign a maximum of four foreign players. The foreign players must meet certain requirements, including having a minimum number of international caps.

# Awards

## Top scorers

The top scorer in Liga 1 is awarded the Golden Boot award. The award is presented by the PSSI at the end of each season.

## Best players

## Best coaches

## Best goals

## Fair play teams

The team with the best fair play record in Liga 1 is awarded the Fair Play award. The award is presented by the PSSI at the end of each season.

## Best referees

The best referee in Liga 1 is awarded the Best Referee award. The award is presented by the PSSI at the end of each season.

# Sponsorship

Liga 1 is sponsored by several companies, including PT Liga Indonesia, which is the league's main sponsor.

# Media coverage

## Current

Liga 1 is broadcast on several television channels, including SCTV and Indosiar. The league is also streamed online on several platforms, including Vidio and Mola.

article:
2022 Fijian General Election

The 2022 Fijian general election was held on December 14, 2022, to elect the 55 members of the Parliament of Fiji. The election was the third since the 2013 Constitution was adopted, which established a mixed-member proportional representation voting system.

# Background

The 2018 Fijian general election saw the FijiFirst party, led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama, win a narrow victory, securing 27 seats in the 51-member Parliament. However, the opposition parties, led by the Social Democratic Liberal Party (SODELPA), gained significant ground, winning 21 seats. The National Federation Party (NFP) won 3 seats, and the Fiji Labour Party (FLP) won 1 seat.

In the lead-up to the 2022 election, Fiji experienced significant economic growth, driven by the tourism and agriculture sectors. However, the country also faced challenges, including a significant increase in the cost of living, a shortage of housing, and concerns about corruption and transparency.

# Electoral System

Fiji uses a mixed-member proportional representation voting system, where voters cast two ballots: one for a local member of Parliament and one for a national party. The local member is elected using a first-past-the-post system, while the national party vote is used to allocate seats in Parliament based on the percentage of votes received.

## Voters

All Fijian citizens aged 18 and over are eligible to vote. The electoral roll was updated in 2022, with over 600,000 registered voters.

## Electoral Changes

The 2022 election saw several electoral changes, including the introduction of a new voter registration system and the use of electronic voting machines in some polling stations.

# Schedule

The election was held on December 14, 2022, with polling stations open from 7:30 am to 6:00 pm. The counting of votes began immediately after the polls closed, with the first results expected to be announced on the evening of December 14.

# Parties

A total of 8 parties contested the election, including the incumbent FijiFirst party, SODELPA, the NFP, the FLP, and the newly formed People's Alliance.

# Campaign

The campaign period began on November 26, 2022, and lasted for 18 days. The campaign was marked by a series of debates, rallies, and public meetings, with parties focusing on key issues such as the economy, education, and healthcare.

## FijiFirst

The FijiFirst party, led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama, campaigned on its record of economic growth and stability. The party promised to continue its policies of investing in infrastructure, education, and healthcare.

## SODELPA

The SODELPA party, led by Viliame Gavoka, campaigned on a platform of change, promising to address the high cost of living, improve access to education and healthcare, and tackle corruption.

## People's Alliance

The People's Alliance, led by Sitiveni Rabuka, campaigned on a platform of unity and inclusivity, promising to bring together Fijians from all backgrounds and to address the country's social and economic challenges.

## NFP

The NFP, led by Pio Tikoduadua, campaigned on a platform of social justice, promising to address the needs of the country's most vulnerable citizens and to promote economic development.

## FLP

The FLP, led by Mahendra Chaudhry, campaigned on a platform of workers' rights, promising to promote the interests of Fijian workers and to address the country's economic challenges.

## All People's

The All People's party, led by Prem Singh, campaigned on a platform of inclusivity and social justice, promising to promote the rights of all Fijian citizens and to address the country's social and economic challenges.

# Opinion Polls

A series of opinion polls were conducted in the lead-up to the election, with the results showing a tight contest between the FijiFirst party and the opposition parties.

## Preferred Prime Minister

A poll conducted by the Fiji Times in November 2022 showed that Frank Bainimarama was the preferred prime minister, with 34% of respondents supporting him. Viliame Gavoka was second, with 23% of respondents supporting him.

## Voting Intention

A poll conducted by the University of the South Pacific in November 2022 showed that 35% of respondents intended to vote for the FijiFirst party, while 28% intended to vote for SODELPA.

## Forecast

Based on the opinion polls, most analysts predicted a close contest between the FijiFirst party and the opposition parties, with the possibility of a hung Parliament.

# Debates

A series of debates were held during the campaign period, with party leaders debating on key issues such as the economy, education, and healthcare.

# Conduct

The election was generally peaceful, with no major incidents reported. However, there were some concerns about the conduct of the campaign, with allegations of vote-buying and intimidation.

# Results

The results of the election were announced on December 15, 2022, with the FijiFirst party winning 26 seats, SODELPA winning 24 seats, the People's Alliance winning 3 seats, and the NFP winning 2 seats.

## Elected Members

A total of 55 members were elected to Parliament, with the FijiFirst party winning the most seats.

# Government Formation

The FijiFirst party, led by Frank Bainimarama, formed a government, with the support of the People's Alliance and the NFP.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of the election was marked by controversy, with allegations of electoral irregularities and disputes over the outcome.

## Election Night Controversy

There were allegations of irregularities on election night, with some parties claiming that the counting process was flawed.

## SODELPA Leadership

The SODELPA party was plunged into crisis, with Viliame Gavoka facing challenges to his leadership.

## Military Deployment

The military was deployed to maintain order, following concerns about public safety.

# Reactions

The reaction to the election was mixed, with some parties accepting the outcome and others disputing it.

## Domestic Relations

The election had significant implications for domestic relations, with the new government facing challenges in addressing the country's social and economic challenges.

## International Reactions

The international community welcomed the peaceful conduct of the election, but expressed concerns about the allegations of electoral irregularities.

article:
Carl Friedrich Gauss
=====================

Carl Friedrich Gauss (1777-1855) was a German mathematician, physicist, and astronomer who made significant contributions to various fields of science and mathematics. He is considered one of the most influential mathematicians of all time, and his work had a profound impact on the development of modern mathematics, physics, and astronomy.

Biography
----------

### Youth and education

Carl Friedrich Gauss was born on April 30, 1777, in Braunschweig, Duchy of Brunswick (now part of Germany), to a family of modest means. His father, Gebhard Dietrich Gauss, was a gardener and a bricklayer, and his mother, Dorothea Benze, was a homemaker. Gauss showed exceptional mathematical talent from an early age and was largely self-taught. He attended the local elementary school, where he impressed his teachers with his mathematical abilities.

In 1788, Gauss entered the Catharineum, a prestigious secondary school in Braunschweig, where he continued to excel in mathematics. Two years later, he entered the University of Göttingen, where he studied mathematics, physics, and philosophy. Gauss's time at Göttingen was marked by significant mathematical discoveries, including the fundamental theorem of algebra and the prime number theorem.

### Private scholar

After completing his studies at Göttingen, Gauss returned to Braunschweig and lived as a private scholar, supported by a stipend from the Duke of Brunswick. During this period, he continued to work on mathematics and astronomy, making significant contributions to both fields.

### Professor in Göttingen

In 1807, Gauss was appointed as the director of the Göttingen Observatory, a position he held until his death in 1855. He was also appointed as a professor of mathematics and astronomy at the University of Göttingen, where he taught and conducted research for many years.

### Gauss's brain

Gauss's brain was preserved after his death and studied by neurologists. It was found to have a unique structure, with a higher-than-average number of neurons and a larger-than-average cerebral cortex. This has led some researchers to speculate about the relationship between brain structure and mathematical ability.

### Family

Gauss married Johanna Osthoff in 1805, and they had three children together. After Johanna's death in 1809, Gauss married Minna Waldeck in 1810, and they had three more children.

### Personality

#### Scholar

Gauss was known for his exceptional mathematical talent and his meticulous approach to research. He was a perfectionist and was known to be very critical of his own work. Gauss was also a prolific writer and corresponded with many prominent mathematicians and scientists of his time.

#### Private man

Gauss was a private person and kept his personal life separate from his professional life. He was known to be quiet and reserved, preferring the company of his family and close friends to that of large social gatherings.

Scientific work
---------------

### Algebra and number theory

Gauss made significant contributions to algebra and number theory, including the fundamental theorem of algebra and the prime number theorem.

#### Fundamental theorem of algebra

The fundamental theorem of algebra states that every non-constant polynomial has at least one complex root. Gauss proved this theorem in his doctoral dissertation and it has since become a cornerstone of algebra.

#### Disquisitiones Arithmeticae

Gauss's most famous work is his book "Disquisitiones Arithmeticae", which was published in 1801. In this book, Gauss presents a comprehensive treatment of number theory, including the properties of integers, congruences, and Diophantine equations.

#### Further investigations

Gauss continued to work on number theory throughout his career, making significant contributions to the study of prime numbers, modular forms, and elliptic curves.

### Analysis

Gauss made significant contributions to analysis, including the development of the theory of functions and the study of differential equations.

#### Numeric analysis

Gauss developed the method of least squares, which is a fundamental technique in statistics and data analysis. He also worked on the study of interpolation and approximation.

### Chronology

Gauss's work on chronology, the study of the measurement of time, led to the development of a new system of timekeeping.

### Astronomy

Gauss made significant contributions to astronomy, including the discovery of the planet Ceres and the calculation of the orbits of the planets.

### Theory of errors

Gauss developed the theory of errors, which is a fundamental concept in statistics and data analysis. He showed that the mean of a large number of measurements is the best estimate of the true value.

### Arc measurement and geodetic survey

Gauss worked on the measurement of the arc of the meridian, which led to a more accurate determination of the size and shape of the Earth.

### Differential geometry

Gauss made significant contributions to differential geometry, including the development of the theory of curvature and the study of surfaces.

### Non-Euclidean geometry

Gauss worked on non-Euclidean geometry, which is a branch of mathematics that deals with geometries that are different from Euclid's geometry.

### Early topology

Gauss made significant contributions to topology, including the development of the theory of knots and the study of the properties of spaces.

### Minor mathematical accomplishments

Gauss made many minor mathematical accomplishments, including the solution of the problem of the seven bridges of Königsberg and the study of the properties of the lemniscate.

### Magnetism and telegraphy

Gauss made significant contributions to the study of magnetism and telegraphy.

#### Geomagnetism

Gauss worked on the study of the Earth's magnetic field and developed a theory of geomagnetism.

#### Electromagnetism

Gauss developed a theory of electromagnetism, which is a fundamental concept in physics.

### Potential theory

Gauss developed the theory of potential, which is a fundamental concept in physics and engineering.

### Optics

Gauss made significant contributions to optics, including the study of the properties of lenses and the behavior of light.

### Mechanics

Gauss worked on the study of mechanics, including the development of the theory of motion and the study of the properties of rigid bodies.

### Metrology

Gauss worked on the study of metrology, including the development of new methods of measurement and the study of the properties of units.

Anecdotes
----------

Gauss was known for his wit and his sense of humor. One famous anecdote about Gauss is that he was once asked by a student to explain a concept in a simpler way. Gauss replied, "I have not the slightest idea what you are talking about."

Honours and awards
-------------------

Gauss received many honors and awards during his lifetime, including the Copley Medal and the Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society.

Names and commemorations
------------------------

Gauss's name has been given to many mathematical concepts, including the Gaussian distribution, the Gaussian curvature, and the Gaussian elimination. He is also commemorated in the Gauss crater on the Moon.

Selected writings
-----------------

### Mathematics and astronomy

* "Disquisitiones Arithmeticae" (1801)
* "Theoria motus corporum coelestium" (1809)
* "Theoria combinationis observationum erroribus minimis obnoxiae" (1821)

### Physics

* "General theory of terrestrial magnetism" (1839)
* "On the motion of the poles of the Earth" (1840)

#### Together with Wilhelm Weber

* "Resultate aus den Beobachtungen des magnetischen Vereins" (1838)

### Collected works

* "Werke" (12 volumes, published posthumously)

### Correspondence

* "Briefwechsel zwischen Gauss und Bessel" (published posthumously)
* "Briefwechsel zwischen Gauss und Gerling" (published posthumously)

Giorgio Napolitano

Giorgio Napolitano is an Italian politician who served as the 11th President of Italy from 2006 to 2015. He is a leading figure in Italian politics and has played a significant role in shaping the country's history. Napolitano's presidency was marked by significant events and challenges, including the European sovereign-debt crisis, the resignation of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, and the rise of new political forces in Italy.

#Early life

Giorgio Napolitano was born on June 29, 1925, in Naples, Italy. His father, Giovanni Napolitano, was a lawyer and a socialist, and his mother, Carolina Bobbio, was a housewife. Napolitano grew up in a liberal and anti-fascist family environment, which had a significant influence on his future political views. He studied law at the University of Naples Federico II, where he graduated in 1947.

#Early political career

##World War II and anti-fascist resistance

During World War II, Napolitano joined the Italian Resistance, a movement that opposed the fascist regime of Benito Mussolini and the German occupation of Italy. He was involved in various anti-fascist activities, including distributing leaflets and participating in demonstrations. After the war, Napolitano became a member of the Italian Communist Party (PCI), which was one of the main forces in the Italian Resistance.

##From post-war years to the Hungarian Revolution of 1956

In the post-war years, Napolitano became increasingly involved in politics. He was elected to the Italian Chamber of Deputies in 1953 and served as a member of the Communist Party's central committee. During the 1950s, Napolitano was a strong supporter of the Soviet Union and its communist ideology. However, the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, which was brutally suppressed by Soviet troops, marked a turning point in his views. Napolitano began to question the Soviet model and the PCI's close ties with Moscow.

#Leading member of the Italian Communist Party

##From the 1960s to 1980s

In the 1960s and 1970s, Napolitano emerged as one of the leading figures in the Italian Communist Party. He was a key proponent of the party's new strategy, which emphasized the need for reforms and a more democratic approach. Napolitano was also a strong advocate for European integration and played a significant role in Italy's accession to the European Community (EC) in 1958. In the 1980s, Napolitano became the PCI's president, a position he held until the party's dissolution in 1991.

#After the Italian Communist Party

##President of the Chamber of Deputies

In 1992, Napolitano was elected President of the Chamber of Deputies, a position he held until 1994. During his presidency, he played a key role in the country's transition from a proportional representation system to a mixed-member majoritarian system.

##Late 1990s and early 2000s

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Napolitano became increasingly involved in European politics. He was a strong supporter of the European Union's (EU) constitutional treaty and played a significant role in Italy's ratification process. Napolitano also served as a member of the European Convention, which drafted the EU's constitutional treaty.

#President of Italy

##First term (2006–2013)

###Election

On May 10, 2006, Napolitano was elected President of Italy, succeeding Carlo Azeglio Ciampi. He was the first former communist to hold the office.

###Prodi Cabinet

Napolitano's presidency was marked by significant challenges, including the European sovereign-debt crisis. In 2006, he appointed Romano Prodi as Prime Minister, who formed a center-left government. However, the government was short-lived and collapsed in 2008.

###2008 political crisis

In 2008, Napolitano faced a major political crisis when the Prodi government collapsed. He played a key role in mediating between the different parties and eventually appointed Silvio Berlusconi as Prime Minister.

###Eluana Englaro incident

In 2009, Napolitano faced criticism for his handling of the Eluana Englaro case, in which a woman in a coma was at the center of a right-to-die debate. Napolitano was accused of intervening in the case and ordering the woman's feeding tube to be reinserted.

###2011 political crisis

In 2011, Napolitano faced another major crisis when the Berlusconi government collapsed. He played a key role in mediating between the different parties and eventually appointed Mario Monti as Prime Minister.

##Second term (2013–2015)

###Re-election

On April 20, 2013, Napolitano was re-elected President of Italy, becoming the first president to serve a second term.

###Letta Cabinet

Napolitano appointed Enrico Letta as Prime Minister, who formed a grand coalition government.

###Renzi Cabinet

In 2014, Napolitano appointed Matteo Renzi as Prime Minister, who formed a center-left government.

##Resignation

On January 14, 2015, Napolitano resigned as President of Italy, citing age and health reasons.

##Later life

After his resignation, Napolitano retired from public life. However, he remains a respected figure in Italian politics and continues to be involved in various initiatives and organizations.

#Personal life

##Relations with the Catholic Church

Napolitano has had a complex relationship with the Catholic Church throughout his life. As a communist, he was critical of the Church's role in Italian society. However, in recent years, he has sought to improve relations with the Church and has met with several popes, including Pope Francis.

##Death and state funeral

Giorgio Napolitano passed away on August 22, 2023, at the age of 98. He was given a state funeral, which was attended by dignitaries from across Italy and Europe.

#Legacy

Napolitano's presidency was marked by significant events and challenges, including the European sovereign-debt crisis and the rise of new political forces in Italy. He played a key role in shaping Italy's response to these challenges and remains a respected figure in Italian politics.

article:
Polar Bear
================

The polar bear (Ursus maritimus) is the largest land carnivore on Earth, with adult males weighing up to 800 kg (1,764 lb) and measuring up to 3 m (10 ft) in length. Native to the Arctic region, the polar bear is well adapted to its harsh, icy environment, with a thick layer of fat and a white coat that helps it blend in with its surroundings. The polar bear is a highly specialized species that plays a crucial role in the Arctic ecosystem, and its conservation status is of great concern due to the impact of climate change on its habitat.

Naming
-------

The name "polar bear" is derived from the Greek word "arktos," meaning "bear," and the Latin word "maritimus," meaning "of the sea." The scientific name "Ursus maritimus" was first used by the Swedish botanist and zoologist Carolus Linnaeus in 1758.

Taxonomy
---------

The polar bear is a member of the family Ursidae and is closely related to the brown bear (Ursus arctos). The two species are thought to have diverged from a common ancestor around 200,000 years ago. There are two subspecies of polar bear: the nominate subspecies (Ursus maritimus maritimus) and the sea-ice bear (Ursus maritimus marinus).

### Evolution

The polar bear is thought to have evolved from a brown bear-like ancestor that lived in the northern hemisphere during the Pleistocene era. The earliest known fossil evidence of polar bears dates back to around 100,000 years ago. Over time, the polar bear adapted to its Arctic environment, developing a range of specialized features such as a white coat, a layer of fat, and large paws that act as snowshoes.

Characteristics
---------------

The polar bear is a large, carnivorous mammal with a range of distinctive characteristics. Adult males typically weigh between 350-700 kg (772-1,543 lb), while females typically weigh between 150-300 kg (331-661 lb). The polar bear's body is well adapted to its Arctic environment, with a thick layer of fat (up to 4 cm or 1.6 in thick) and a white coat that helps it blend in with its surroundings. The polar bear's fur is made up of two layers: a thick undercoat and a longer, guard hair layer. The guard hairs are transparent and hollow, which helps to scatter and reflect sunlight and give the polar bear its white appearance.

Distribution and Habitat
-------------------------

The polar bear is found in the Arctic region, including Alaska, Canada, Greenland, Norway, and Russia. The polar bear's habitat is typically sea ice, which it uses as a platform to hunt and feed on seals. The polar bear is also found on land, particularly during the summer months when the sea ice melts. In these areas, the polar bear will often feed on berries, lichens, and other vegetation.

Behaviour and Ecology
----------------------

The polar bear is a highly specialized species that plays a crucial role in the Arctic ecosystem. Its behavior and ecology are closely tied to its sea ice habitat, and it is well adapted to its harsh, icy environment.

### Social Life

Polar bears are generally solitary animals, only coming together to mate or to feed on a carcass. Female polar bears will often care for their young, teaching them important survival skills such as hunting and swimming. Male polar bears will often engage in play-fighting, which helps to establish dominance and develop important skills such as hunting and defense.

### Diet and Hunting

The polar bear's diet consists mainly of seals, which it hunts using a range of strategies such as stalking, ambushing, and waiting at breathing holes. The polar bear will also feed on other marine mammals such as walruses and belugas, as well as carrion and other land-based prey. The polar bear is a skilled hunter, with a highly developed sense of smell and excellent eyesight.

### Reproduction and Development

Female polar bears typically give birth to two cubs per litter, which are born blind and helpless. The cubs will nurse for around 18-24 months, during which time they will develop important survival skills such as hunting and swimming. Male polar bears will often play a role in caring for the cubs, teaching them important skills such as hunting and defense.

### Mortality

Polar bears can live for up to 25-30 years in the wild, although the average lifespan is around 15-18 years. The main causes of mortality for polar bears are starvation, drowning, and human-caused mortality such as hunting and poaching.

Conservation Status
-------------------

The polar bear is listed as "vulnerable" on the IUCN Red List, due to the impact of climate change on its sea ice habitat. The polar bear's population is projected to decline by 30% by 2050, due to the loss of sea ice and the resulting impact on its ability to hunt and feed.

Relationship with Humans
-----------------------

The polar bear has a complex and often conflicted relationship with humans, ranging from exploitation and conflict to conservation and admiration.

### Exploitation

Polar bears have been hunted for their fur, meat, and body parts, which are used in traditional medicine. The hunting of polar bears is regulated by international law, although poaching remains a significant threat to the species.

### Conflicts

Polar bears and humans often come into conflict, particularly in areas where their habitats overlap. Polar bears may attack humans in self-defense, or when they are attracted to human food or waste. Humans may also attack polar bears in self-defense, or when they are protecting their property or livelihoods.

### Captivity

Polar bears are often kept in captivity in zoos and aquariums, where they are used for education and conservation purposes. However, the keeping of polar bears in captivity is often controversial, due to concerns about animal welfare and the impact of captivity on the species.

### Cultural Significance

The polar bear has significant cultural and symbolic meaning, particularly in the Arctic region. The polar bear is often seen as a symbol of strength, resilience, and adaptability, and is featured in the mythology and folklore of many Arctic cultures.

article:
Russian cruiser Moskva

The Russian cruiser Moskva was a Slava-class guided missile cruiser that served as the flagship of the Russian Black Sea Fleet. Commissioned in 1983 as Slava, the ship was later renamed Moskva in 1995. During its service, the Moskva played a significant role in various naval operations and exercises, including the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

# History

## As Slava

The Slava was laid down on November 28, 1976, at the 61 Kommunara Shipbuilding Plant in Mykolaiv, Ukraine. The ship was launched on July 27, 1979, and commissioned into the Soviet Navy on January 30, 1983. Initially, the Slava was assigned to the Soviet Black Sea Fleet, with its homeport in Sevastopol, Crimea.

In the early 1990s, following the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Slava underwent a major overhaul, which included the installation of new radar and electronic warfare systems. The ship also received a new coat of paint and underwent minor repairs.

## As Moskva

In 1995, the Slava was renamed Moskva, in honor of the Russian capital city. The renaming ceremony took place on May 16, 1995, at the ship's homeport in Sevastopol. After the renaming, the Moskva continued to serve as the flagship of the Russian Black Sea Fleet.

Throughout the late 1990s and early 2000s, the Moskva participated in various naval exercises and operations, including joint exercises with other Russian naval vessels and international exercises with NATO member countries. In 2003, the Moskva visited the Greek port city of Piraeus, where it participated in a naval parade.

## Russian invasion of Ukraine

In 2014, the Moskva played a significant role in the Russian annexation of Crimea, which took place during the Ukrainian revolution. The ship served as a command center for Russian naval operations in the region.

### Snake Island campaign

In August 2021, the Moskva was involved in a dispute with Ukraine over the status of Snake Island, a small island in the Black Sea that is claimed by both Russia and Ukraine. The ship was deployed to the area to support Russian claims to the island.

On August 23, 2021, the Moskva intercepted a Ukrainian naval vessel that was attempting to approach the island. The incident sparked a diplomatic row between Russia and Ukraine, with both countries accusing each other of aggression.

### Sinking

On April 13, 2022, during the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the Moskva was reportedly sunk by a Ukrainian Neptune anti-ship missile while it was operating in the Black Sea. The incident occurred about 80 kilometers (50 miles) south of the Ukrainian port city of Odesa.

According to Russian officials, the ship suffered a fire and was damaged, but it was not sunk. However, Ukrainian officials claimed that the ship had been sunk, and that all crew members on board had been killed.

The sinking of the Moskva was widely reported in international media, and it was seen as a significant blow to the Russian Navy. The incident marked one of the most significant losses for the Russian military during the invasion of Ukraine.

# Notes

* The Moskva was the third ship of the Slava-class to be built, following the Slava and the Marshal Ustinov.
* The ship was powered by two gas turbines, which provided a total output of 110,000 horsepower.
* The Moskva was armed with a range of weapons, including anti-ship missiles, anti-aircraft missiles, and torpedoes.
* The ship had a crew of approximately 500 personnel.

2022 UEFA Champions League Final

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was the final match of the 2021-22 UEFA Champions League, the 67th season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by UEFA, and the 30th season since it was renamed from the European Cup to the UEFA Champions League. The match was played at the Stade de France in Saint-Denis, a suburb of Paris, France, on May 28, 2022.

Background
----------

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was the culmination of the 2021-22 UEFA Champions League, which began on September 14, 2021, with the group stage draw. A total of 80 teams from 54 UEFA member associations participated in the competition, with the top four teams from the top four associations (Spain, England, Germany, and Italy) qualifying directly for the group stage, while the remaining teams competed in the qualifying rounds.

### Previous finals

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was the first European Cup/UEFA Champions League final to be played at the Stade de France since 2006, when Barcelona defeated Arsenal 2-1. The two finalists, Real Madrid and Liverpool, had previously met in the 2018 UEFA Champions League Final, which Real Madrid won 3-1.

Venue
------

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was played at the Stade de France in Saint-Denis, a suburb of Paris, France. The stadium has a seating capacity of 81,338 and has hosted numerous high-profile football matches, including the 1998 FIFA World Cup Final and the 2006 UEFA Champions League Final.

### Host selection

The host city for the 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was selected by the UEFA Executive Committee on September 24, 2020. The Stade de France was chosen as the host venue ahead of the Allianz Arena in Munich, Germany, and the Johan Cruyff Arena in Amsterdam, Netherlands.

Route to the final
-------------------

### Real Madrid

Real Madrid qualified for the 2021-22 UEFA Champions League as the 2020-21 La Liga champions. They were drawn into Group D alongside Inter Milan, Sheriff Tiraspol, and Shakhtar Donetsk, and finished top of the group with 15 points from six matches. In the knockout phase, Real Madrid defeated Paris Saint-Germain 3-2 on aggregate in the round of 16, Chelsea 5-4 on aggregate in the quarterfinals, and Manchester City 6-5 on aggregate in the semifinals.

### Liverpool

Liverpool qualified for the 2021-22 UEFA Champions League as the 2020-21 Premier League runners-up. They were drawn into Group B alongside Atlético Madrid, Porto, and AC Milan, and finished top of the group with 18 points from six matches. In the knockout phase, Liverpool defeated Inter Milan 2-1 on aggregate in the round of 16, Benfica 6-4 on aggregate in the quarterfinals, and Villarreal 5-2 on aggregate in the semifinals.

Pre-match
----------

### Identity

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final identity was unveiled on August 26, 2021. The logo features a stylized design that incorporates the colors of the French flag, as well as the UEFA Champions League trophy.

### Officials

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was refereed by Clément Turpin of France. The assistant referees were Nicolas Danos and Cyril Gringore, while the fourth official was Benoît Bastien, all from France. The video assistant referee (VAR) was Jérôme Brisard, also from France.

### Opening ceremony

The opening ceremony for the 2022 UEFA Champions League Final took place at 8:40 PM CEST (UTC+2) on May 28, 2022. The ceremony featured a performance by American singer Camila Cabello, as well as a display of pyrotechnics and fireworks.

### Issues entering stadium and match delay

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was delayed by 36 minutes due to issues with fans entering the stadium. The match was originally scheduled to kick off at 9:00 PM CEST (UTC+2), but was pushed back to 9:36 PM CEST (UTC+2) due to congestion outside the stadium.

------

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was played between Real Madrid and Liverpool at the Stade de France in Saint-Denis, France, on May 28, 2022. Real Madrid won the match 1-0, with a goal from Vinícius Júnior in the 59th minute.

#### First half

The first half of the 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was a closely contested affair, with both teams creating scoring opportunities. Real Madrid had the best chance of the half, with Karim Benzema's shot being saved by Liverpool goalkeeper Alisson in the 22nd minute.

#### Second half

The second half of the 2022 UEFA Champions League Final saw Real Madrid take control of the match. Vinícius Júnior scored the winning goal in the 59th minute, after a pass from Federico Valverde. Liverpool pushed hard for an equalizer, but were unable to break down the Real Madrid defense.

article:
Badin District
================

Badin District is one of the 29 districts of Sindh province, Pakistan. It is situated in the southern part of the province, bordering the Arabian Sea to the south and the districts of Tharparkar to the east, Mirpurkhas to the north, and Thatta to the west. The district capital, Badin, is the largest city in the district and serves as the administrative and economic hub.

History
-------

The region of Badin has a rich and diverse history dating back to the ancient Indus Valley Civilization. The district was an important center of trade and commerce during the medieval period, with the port city of Shahbandar (now a small fishing village) serving as a major hub for maritime trade. In the 18th century, the region was conquered by the Kalhora dynasty, which ruled the area until it was annexed by the British East India Company in 1843. During the British colonial period, the district was known as the "Shahbandar District" and was an important center for the production of cotton, wheat, and other crops.

Demographics
------------

### Religion

According to the 2017 census, the population of Badin District is predominantly Muslim, with 96.5% of the population identifying as Muslim. The remaining 3.5% of the population includes Hindus, Christians, and other minority groups.

### Language

The predominant language spoken in the district is Sindhi, which is spoken by approximately 85% of the population. Other languages spoken in the district include Urdu, Punjabi, and Pashto.

Administration
--------------

### List of Tehsils

Badin District is divided into five tehsils:

1. Badin Tehsil
2. Golarchi Tehsil
3. Matli Tehsil
4. Nindo Shahar Tehsil
5. Tando Bago Tehsil

### List of Union Councils

The district is further divided into 59 union councils:

1. Badin (UC-1 to UC-5)
2. Golarchi (UC-6 to UC-12)
3. Matli (UC-13 to UC-19)
4. Nindo Shahar (UC-20 to UC-26)
5. Tando Bago (UC-27 to UC-33)
6. Pangrio (UC-34 to UC-39)
7. Kadhan (UC-40 to UC-45)
8. Khoski (UC-46 to UC-51)
9. Shaheed Fazil Rahu (UC-52 to UC-57)
10. Dighri (UC-58 to UC-59)

### List of Dehs

The district is divided into 243 dehs:

1. Badin Tehsil (43 dehs)
2. Golarchi Tehsil (44 dehs)
3. Matli Tehsil (41 dehs)
4. Nindo Shahar Tehsil (36 dehs)
5. Tando Bago Tehsil (37 dehs)
6. Pangrio (21 dehs)
7. Kadhan (20 dehs)
8. Khoski (24 dehs)
9. Shaheed Fazil Rahu (22 dehs)
10. Dighri (19 dehs)

Education
----------

Badin District has a literacy rate of 55.6%, with 65.5% of males and 44.5% of females able to read and write. The district has a total of 1,443 schools, including 723 primary schools, 244 middle schools, 246 high schools, and 230 higher secondary schools. The district is also home to the Badin Degree College, which provides higher education in arts, commerce, and science.

Economy
-------

The economy of Badin District is primarily based on agriculture, with the main crops being cotton, wheat, sugarcane, and rice. The district is also known for its production of fruits and vegetables, including mangoes, bananas, and tomatoes.

### Railways

The district is connected to the rest of the country through a railway line that runs from Badin to Hyderabad. The Badin railway station is an important stop on this line and provides transportation services to passengers and freight.

### Badin Coal Field

The Badin Coal Field is a large coal deposit located in the district. The coal field was discovered in the 1970s and has since been mined by the Pakistan Mineral Development Corporation. The coal is primarily used for the production of electricity and is an important source of revenue for the district.

References
----------

Boys Planet is a 2023 South Korean reality competition television series created by Mnet, a subsidiary of CJ E&M. The show is designed to create a new K-pop boy group through a competition among 98 trainees from various entertainment companies. The series premiered on February 2, 2023, and concluded on April 20, 2023.

#Concept and format

Boys Planet is a talent competition show that brings together 98 trainees from different entertainment companies to compete against each other. The contestants undergo various challenges and evaluations, and the top 9 trainees with the most votes will debut as a new K-pop boy group.

##Voting system

The voting system on Boys Planet is a combination of online voting and in-studio voting. Viewers can vote for their favorite contestants through the show's official website and mobile app. The contestants with the most votes will receive a higher ranking and a greater chance of debuting in the final group.

article:
2021–22 European windstorm season

The 2021–22 European windstorm season was the fifth season of the European windstorm naming system, in which storms that affected Europe were named by various meteorological agencies. The season began on September 1, 2021, and ended on August 31, 2022.

# Background and naming

The European windstorm naming system was established in 2017 to provide a consistent and clear way of communicating the risk of severe weather to the public. The system involves naming storms that meet certain criteria, such as wind speeds of at least 65 km/h (40 mph) or the potential to cause significant disruption.

## Western Group (United Kingdom, Ireland and the Netherlands)

The Western Group consists of the United Kingdom, Ireland, and the Netherlands. Storms that affect these countries are named by the Met Office, Met Éireann, and the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI). The Met Office uses a list of names that are chosen from a pool of suggestions submitted by the public.

## South-western Group (France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium and Luxembourg)

The South-western Group consists of France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg. Storms that affect these countries are named by Météo-France, the Spanish State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), the Portuguese Institute for the Sea and the Atmosphere (IPMA), the Royal Meteorological Institute of Belgium (RMI), and the Luxembourg Institute of Meteorology and Hydrology (IMH).

## Eastern Mediterranean Group (Greece, Israel and Cyprus)

The Eastern Mediterranean Group consists of Greece, Israel, and Cyprus. Storms that affect these countries are named by the Hellenic National Meteorological Service (HNMS), the Israel Meteorological Service (IMS), and the Cyprus Meteorological Service (CMS).

## Central Mediterranean Group (Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Malta)

The Central Mediterranean Group consists of Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta. Storms that affect these countries are named by the Italian National Institute of Meteorology and Climate Science (ARPAE), the Slovenian Environment Agency (ARSO), the Croatian Meteorological and Hydrological Service (DHMZ), the Montenegrin Hydrological and Meteorological Service (HMS), the North Macedonian Hydrometeorological Service (HMS), and the Maltese National Meteorological Service (MMS).

## Northern Group (Iceland, Denmark, Norway, Finland and Sweden)

The Northern Group consists of Iceland, Denmark, Norway, Finland, and Sweden. Storms that affect these countries are named by the Icelandic Met Office, the Danish Meteorological Institute (DMI), the Norwegian Meteorological Institute (MET Norway), the Finnish Meteorological Institute (FMI), and the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI).

# Season summary

The 2021–22 European windstorm season was marked by a series of intense storms that affected various parts of Europe. The season began with a relatively quiet period, but activity increased in the winter months. Some of the most notable storms of the season include Storm Arwen, which caused widespread disruption in the United Kingdom, and Storm Eunice, which brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of western Europe.

# Storms

## Storm Athina (Christian)

Storm Athina was the first named storm of the season, affecting Greece and Turkey in early September. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to the region, causing some disruption.

## Storm Ballos

Storm Ballos was a powerful storm that affected Greece and the eastern Mediterranean in mid-September. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to the region, causing significant disruption.

## Storm Aurore (Hendrik)

Storm Aurore was a strong storm that affected western Europe in late September. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of the United Kingdom, France, and Germany.

## Cyclone Apollo

Cyclone Apollo was a powerful storm that affected the Mediterranean in early October. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Italy, Greece, and Turkey.

## Storm Blas

Storm Blas was a strong storm that affected the Iberian Peninsula in mid-October. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Spain and Portugal.

## Storm Arwen

Storm Arwen was a powerful storm that affected the United Kingdom and Ireland in late November. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to the region, causing widespread disruption.

## Storm Barra (Harry)

Storm Barra was a strong storm that affected the United Kingdom and Ireland in early December. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to the region, causing significant disruption.

## Storm Carmel

Storm Carmel was a strong storm that affected the eastern Mediterranean in mid-December. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Greece, Turkey, and Israel.

## Storm Diomedes (Doreen)

Storm Diomedes was a powerful storm that affected the Balkans in late December. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Greece, Bulgaria, and Romania.

## Storm Elpis

Storm Elpis was a strong storm that affected the eastern Mediterranean in early January. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Greece, Turkey, and Israel.

## Storm Malik

Storm Malik was a powerful storm that affected northern Europe in mid-January. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of the United Kingdom, Norway, and Sweden.

## Storm Corrie

Storm Corrie was a strong storm that affected the United Kingdom and Ireland in late January. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to the region, causing significant disruption.

## Storm Dudley

Storm Dudley was a strong storm that affected western Europe in early February. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of the United Kingdom, France, and Germany.

## Storm Eunice

Storm Eunice was a powerful storm that affected western Europe in mid-February. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of the United Kingdom, France, and Germany, causing widespread disruption.

## Storm Franklin

Storm Franklin was a strong storm that affected the United Kingdom and Ireland in late February. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to the region, causing significant disruption.

## Storm Bianca

Storm Bianca was a strong storm that affected the Mediterranean in early March. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Italy, Greece, and Turkey.

## Storm Filippos

Storm Filippos was a powerful storm that affected the eastern Mediterranean in mid-March. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Greece, Turkey, and Israel.

## Storm Celia

Storm Celia was a strong storm that affected the Iberian Peninsula in late March. The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to parts of Spain and Portugal.

## Storm Ciril (Katharina)

article:
2022 Missile Explosion in Poland

On November 15, 2022, a missile exploded in the village of Przewodów, Poland, near the border with Ukraine, killing two people and sparking widespread concern about the potential escalation of the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine. The incident occurred during a large-scale Russian missile strike against Ukrainian cities, with Ukrainian forces firing missiles to intercept the incoming Russian projectiles.

#Background

The 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine had been ongoing since February, with Russia launching a series of missile strikes against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure. Ukraine's air defense systems had been actively engaged in intercepting Russian missiles, with some projectiles falling on Ukrainian territory and others being destroyed in mid-air. Poland, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), had been providing military aid to Ukraine and hosting thousands of Ukrainian refugees fleeing the conflict.

#Explosion

On November 15, 2022, at around 3:40 pm local time, a missile exploded in the village of Przewodów, Poland, approximately 6 kilometers (3.7 miles) from the Ukrainian border. The explosion occurred on a farm, killing two Polish citizens, Bogusław Wos and Bogdan Ciupek, who were working at the site. The blast also damaged a grain dryer and a tractor. Polish authorities immediately launched an investigation into the incident, with the Polish Ministry of Defense confirming that the explosion was caused by a missile.

#Investigation

The Polish government launched a joint investigation with NATO and Ukrainian authorities to determine the origin and circumstances of the missile explosion. Polish President Andrzej Duda stated that the investigation would be conducted in a transparent manner, with all relevant evidence being shared with NATO and Ukrainian officials. Preliminary findings suggested that the missile was a Soviet-era S-300 surface-to-air missile, which was likely fired by Ukrainian forces in response to a Russian missile strike.

#Reactions

##Poland

The Polish government condemned the incident, with President Duda stating that the explosion was a "tragic accident" and expressing condolences to the families of the victims. Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki called an emergency meeting of the Polish National Security Council to discuss the incident and potential responses. Polish authorities also increased military presence along the border with Ukraine as a precautionary measure.

##International

###Russia

The Russian Ministry of Defense denied any involvement in the incident, stating that Russian missiles were not directed at Poland and that the explosion was likely caused by a Ukrainian air defense missile. Russian officials also accused Ukraine of attempting to provoke a conflict with NATO.

###Ukraine

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy expressed condolences to the families of the victims and stated that Ukraine was willing to cooperate with the investigation. Ukrainian officials also denied any intentional targeting of Polish territory, stating that Ukrainian forces were acting in self-defense against Russian missile strikes.

###NATO officials and member countries

NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg condemned the incident, stating that the alliance stood in solidarity with Poland and supported the ongoing investigation. NATO officials also emphasized the importance of de-escalating the conflict and preventing further incidents. Several NATO member countries, including the United States, Germany, and France, expressed support for Poland and called for a thorough investigation.

###Others

The European Union and the United Nations also condemned the incident, calling for restraint and de-escalation. The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) offered to support the investigation and facilitate dialogue between Ukraine and Russia.

#Related incidents

The 2022 missile explosion in Poland was not an isolated incident, with several other cases of missiles and projectiles crossing the border from Ukraine into Poland and other neighboring countries. In October 2022, a Ukrainian S-300 missile landed in the Romanian town of Tulcea, causing no casualties or damage. Similar incidents have also been reported in Moldova and Slovakia.

#See also

* 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
* NATO-Ukraine relations
* Russia-Ukraine relations
* List of incidents during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine

article:
2022 United States House of Representatives elections

The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections were held on November 8, 2022, to elect representatives from all 435 congressional districts across each of the 50 U.S. states. The elections took place in the middle of President Joe Biden's term and coincided with the 2022 Senate elections and various state and local elections. 

# Electoral system

In the United States, members of the House of Representatives are elected using a single-member plurality system, where the candidate with the most votes in a district wins the seat. The number of representatives each state has is based on its population, with a minimum of one representative per state. The representatives serve a term of two years, with all seats up for election every even-numbered year.

article:
2022–23 FC Barcelona season

The 2022–23 season was the 123rd season in the history of FC Barcelona and their 92nd consecutive season in the top flight of Spanish football. In addition to the domestic league, Barcelona participated in this season's editions of the Copa del Rey, Supercopa de España, UEFA Champions League, and UEFA Europa League.

#Kits

The 2022–23 kits were released in June 2022. The home kit features a traditional red and blue stripes design, while the away kit is a white shirt with a black collar and red stripes on the sides. The third kit is a yellow shirt with a black collar and red stripes on the sides.

#Season overview

##Pre-season

The pre-season began on July 4, 2022, with a training session at the Ciutat Esportiva Joan Gamper. The team played several friendly matches, including a 6-0 win against Inter Miami CF and a 1-0 loss against Real Madrid.

##August

The season began on August 13, 2022, with a 0-0 draw against Rayo Vallecano in La Liga. The team then played a 4-1 win against Real Sociedad in the same competition.

##September

On September 7, 2022, Barcelona played a 0-0 draw against Viktoria Plzeň in the UEFA Champions League group stage. The team then played a 3-0 win against Sevilla FC in La Liga.

##October

On October 1, 2022, Barcelona played a 1-1 draw against Inter Milan in the UEFA Champions League group stage. The team then played a 1-0 win against Celta Vigo in La Liga.

##November

On November 8, 2022, Barcelona played a 2-0 win against Viktoria Plzeň in the UEFA Champions League group stage. The team then played a 2-1 win against Osasuna in La Liga.

##December

On December 31, 2022, Barcelona played a 1-1 draw against Espanyol in La Liga.

##January

On January 4, 2023, Barcelona played a 3-1 win against Intercity in the Copa del Rey round of 32. The team then played a 1-0 win against Atlético Madrid in La Liga.

##February

On February 2, 2023, Barcelona played a 1-0 win against Real Sociedad in the Copa del Rey quarterfinals. The team then played a 2-1 win against Villarreal CF in La Liga.

##March

On March 5, 2023, Barcelona played a 1-0 win against Valencia CF in La Liga. The team then played a 1-0 win against Athletic Bilbao in the same competition.

##April

On April 1, 2023, Barcelona played a 1-0 win against Elche CF in La Liga. The team then played a 1-1 draw against Girona FC in the same competition.

##May

On May 4, 2023, Barcelona played a 1-0 win against Real Betis in La Liga. The team then played a 1-1 draw against Espanyol in the same competition.

##June

On June 4, 2023, Barcelona played a 1-1 draw against Real Madrid in La Liga.

article:
2023 Estonian parliamentary election

The 2023 Estonian parliamentary election was held on 5 March 2023 to elect the 101 members of the Riigikogu, the unicameral parliament of Estonia. The election saw the incumbent government, led by Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, face a challenge from opposition parties.

# Background

The 2023 Estonian parliamentary election was the 14th parliamentary election to be held in Estonia since the country regained its independence in 1991. The election was called following the dissolution of the 14th Riigikogu, which was elected in 2019. The election was held in accordance with the Constitution of Estonia, which stipulates that parliamentary elections must be held at least once every four years.

# Electoral system

Estonia uses a proportional representation system to elect its parliament. The country is divided into 12 electoral districts, each of which elects between 5 and 13 members of parliament. Seats are allocated to parties using the d'Hondt method.

## Seats by electoral district

The 12 electoral districts in Estonia are:

## Pre-election composition

The 14th Riigikogu, which was elected in 2019, consisted of six parties: the Estonian Reform Party, the Estonian Centre Party, the Conservative People's Party of Estonia, the Estonian Social Democratic Party, Isamaa, and the Estonian Greens.

# Contesting parties

A total of nine parties contested the 2023 Estonian parliamentary election.

## Party manifestos and slogans

Each of the contesting parties released a manifesto outlining their policies and goals. The Estonian Reform Party's manifesto focused on economic growth and stability, while the Estonian Centre Party's manifesto emphasized the importance of social welfare and public services. The Conservative People's Party of Estonia's manifesto took a more nationalist tone, emphasizing the need to protect Estonian culture and identity.

# Campaign

The campaign for the 2023 Estonian parliamentary election began in earnest in January 2023, with parties launching their manifestos and beginning to campaign in earnest.

## Issues

A number of issues dominated the campaign, including the economy, healthcare, and education. The Estonian Reform Party focused on its record on the economy, while the Estonian Centre Party emphasized the need for greater investment in public services.

## Debates

A series of debates were held during the campaign, featuring representatives from the contesting parties. The debates were broadcast on television and online, and provided an opportunity for voters to hear from the parties and make informed decisions.

# Opinion polls

A number of opinion polls were conducted during the campaign, providing insight into the views of Estonian voters. The polls suggested that the Estonian Reform Party and the Estonian Centre Party were the two most popular parties, with the Conservative People's Party of Estonia also performing strongly.

# Results

The results of the 2023 Estonian parliamentary election were announced on 6 March 2023.

article:
UFC 273: Volkanovski vs. The Korean Zombie was a mixed martial arts event produced by the Ultimate Fighting Championship that took place on April 9, 2022, at the VyStar Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Florida, United States.

# Background

UFC 273 was the 273rd event produced by the Ultimate Fighting Championship and it marked the organization's first visit to Jacksonville, Florida since UFC 249 in 2020. The event was originally scheduled to take place at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York, but was later moved to the VyStar Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Florida due to COVID-19 restrictions.

The event was headlined by a featherweight championship bout between current champion Alexander Volkanovski and challenger Chan Sung Jung, also known as The Korean Zombie. The co-main event featured a bantamweight championship bout between current champion Aljamain Sterling and challenger Petr Yan.

# Results

## Preliminary Card

* Women's Strawweight: Piera Rodriguez defeated Kay Hansen via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28)
* Lightweight: Ricky Glenn defeated Chris Duncan via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28)
* Bantamweight: Chris Gutierrez defeated Batgerel Danaa via TKO (punches) in round 2 (2:34)
* Women's Flyweight: Casey O'Neill defeated Roxanne Modafferi via split decision (29-28, 28-29, 29-28)

## Main Card

* Welterweight: Belal Muhammad defeated Vicente Luque via unanimous decision (49-46, 49-46, 49-47)
* Women's Bantamweight: Raquel Pennington defeated Aspen Ladd via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28)
* Middleweight: Khamzhat Chimaev defeated Gilbert Burns via unanimous decision (29-28, 29-28, 29-28)
* Bantamweight Championship: Aljamain Sterling (c) defeated Petr Yan via split decision (48-47, 47-48, 48-47)
* Featherweight Championship: Alexander Volkanovski (c) defeated Chan Sung Jung via TKO (punches) in round 4 (0:45)

# Bonus Awards

The following fighters received bonus awards:

* Fight of the Night: Belal Muhammad vs. Vicente Luque
* Performance of the Night: Alexander Volkanovski
* Performance of the Night: Khamzhat Chimaev

article:
The Cuphead Show!
================

The Cuphead Show! is a computer-animated television series created by Chad and Jared Moldenhauer, the brothers behind the critically acclaimed video game Cuphead. The show is based on the 1930s cartoon-inspired aesthetic and gameplay of the original game, but presents a new narrative that expands on the characters and world.

Plot
-----

The Cuphead Show! follows the adventures of two brothers, Cuphead and Mugman, as they try to repay a debt to the Devil. The series takes place in the fictional world of Inkwell Isle, where the brothers live in a small house with their caretaker, Elder Kettle. Throughout the series, Cuphead and Mugman embark on various quests and battles against a range of enemies, including the show's main antagonists, the Devil's Henchmen.

The show's narrative is presented in a non-linear fashion, with each episode featuring the brothers facing a new challenge or adversary. Along the way, they meet a range of colorful characters, including King Dice, a smooth-talking, high-rolling gangster, and Cagney Carnation, a charming, flirtatious flower.

Voice cast
------------

The Cuphead Show! features a talented voice cast, including:

* Tru Valentino as Cuphead
* Frank Todaro as Mugman
* Grey DeLisle as King Dice
* Luke Millington-Drake as the Devil
* Cosmo Segurson as Elder Kettle
* Candi Milo as Cagney Carnation

Development
------------

The Cuphead Show! was first announced in July 2019, with Netflix acquiring the rights to adapt the video game into an animated series. The show is produced by King Features Syndicate, a leading producer of animated content, in association with Studio MDHR, the developer of the Cuphead video game.

The show's creators, Chad and Jared Moldenhauer, are heavily involved in the production process, with the brothers serving as executive producers on the series. The show's animation style is inspired by the original video game, but features a range of new characters, locations, and storylines.

Episodes
---------

The first season of The Cuphead Show! consists of 12 episodes, each approximately 11 minutes in length. The episodes are designed to be self-contained, with each featuring a standalone narrative, but there are also ongoing storylines and character arcs throughout the season.

Some notable episodes from the first season include:

* "Carnival Chaos," which introduces the character of Cagney Carnation
* "The Devil's Henchmen," which features the brothers facing off against the show's main antagonists
* "Elder Kettle's Puzzle," which showcases the caretaker's skills as a puzzle solver

Reception
----------

The Cuphead Show! has received widespread critical acclaim, with praise for its unique animation style, engaging characters, and entertaining storylines. The show has been praised for its faithfulness to the original video game, while also introducing new elements and ideas.

Some reviewers have noted that the show's non-linear narrative can be confusing at times, but overall, the show has been well-received by both critics and audiences.

Accolades
----------

The Cuphead Show! has been nominated for several awards, including:

* Annie Award for Best Animated Television Series
* Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program
* Saturn Award for Best Animated Series on Television

article:
Hurricane Lee (2023)

Hurricane Lee was a powerful and destructive tropical cyclone that affected several countries in the North Atlantic in September 2023. The storm caused widespread damage and disruption, particularly in Bermuda, the United States, and Canada.

# Meteorological history

Hurricane Lee formed as a tropical wave off the coast of West Africa on September 1, 2023. The system moved westward across the Atlantic, gradually organizing into a tropical depression on September 5. The depression strengthened into Tropical Storm Lee later that day, and continued to intensify as it moved northwestward.

Lee became a hurricane on September 7, with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph (130 km/h). The storm continued to strengthen, reaching its peak intensity as a Category 4 hurricane on September 10, with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (225 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 955 mbar (28.20 inHg).

Lee began to weaken on September 11, as it encountered unfavorable environmental conditions. The storm made landfall on Bermuda on September 12, causing significant damage and disruption. Lee continued to weaken as it moved northward, making landfall on the eastern coast of the United States on September 14.

# Preparations and impact

2022 Conservative Party of Canada leadership election

The 2022 Conservative Party of Canada leadership election was a leadership election held by the Conservative Party of Canada to elect a new leader to replace Erin O'Toole, who was ousted as leader by the party's caucus in February 2022. The election was won by Pierre Poilievre, a Member of Parliament from Ontario, who was announced as the new leader on September 10, 2022.

# Background

The Conservative Party of Canada has a history of leadership elections, with the most recent one being held in 2020, which saw Erin O'Toole elected as the new leader. However, O'Toole's leadership was short-lived, as he was ousted by the party's caucus in February 2022, following a disappointing performance in the 2021 federal election. The party's national council then initiated a leadership election process to elect a new leader.

# Timeline

The 2020 Conservative Party of Canada leadership election was held in August 2020, which saw Erin O'Toole elected as the new leader. O'Toole won the election on the third ballot, defeating Peter MacKay and Leslyn Lewis.

## 2021

## 2022

In February 2022, O'Toole was ousted as leader by the party's caucus, following a vote of no confidence. The party's national council then initiated a leadership election process to elect a new leader. The election was scheduled to take place in September 2022.

# Rules and procedures

The leadership election was governed by the Conservative Party of Canada's constitution and bylaws. The election was conducted using a ranked-choice voting system, where members ranked their preferred candidates in order of preference. The candidate with the fewest votes was eliminated, and their supporters' second choices were redistributed until a candidate reached a majority of votes.

The campaign for the leadership election was marked by a number of controversies and debates. The candidates focused on issues such as the economy, healthcare, and the environment.
